Instruction_1: City of Toronto residents can drop off up to 10 passenger and light truck tires per day free of charge at some Drop-Off Depots.
Instruction_2: Only passenger and light truck tires will be accepted. All other tire types (e.g., heavy truck, forklift and large off-road tires) will not be accepted.
Instruction_3: Check the Resource Productivity & Recovery Authority website (rpra.ca/programs/tires/collectionsites/) for other tire collection sites.

Item: used cooking oil/olive oil/vegetable oil (large amount)
Instruction_1: Never pour down the sink, drain or toilet because it can cause sewer backups in your home and neighbourhood.
Instruction_2: Bring this item to a City Drop-Off Depot or Community Environment Day in any container that has a lid, is securely closed and can be left behind.
Instruction_3: For HHW from 10-50 L/kg, you can request a free Toxic Taxi pickup online or by calling 311. In an apartment/condo, building staff need to request pickup.

If you find a dead animal, contact 311.
Instruction_2: You can also make an appointment to bring dead animals to a Toronto Animal Shelter for disposal.

Instruction_1: Do not touch the dead animal with your bare hands.
Instruction_2: Wear gloves or use a plastic bag to pick it up and put inside two plastic bags (double bag). Then tie the bags closed and place in the garbage.
Instruction_3: Please do not contact 311 as small wild animal cadavers, whether on City or private property, will not be picked up by Toronto Animal Services.

Instruction_3: For HHW from 10-50 L/kg, you can request a free Toxic Taxi pickup online or by calling 311. In an apartment/condo, building staff need to request pickup.

Instruction_1: Never pour down the sink, drain or toilet because it can cause sewer backups in your home and neighbourhood.

Instruction_1: Batteries are Household Hazardous Waste (HHW) and MUST NOT be placed in the Garbage Bin, Blue Bin or Green Bin.
Instruction_2: For safe storage, place used batteries back in packaging or cover the positive terminal with tape or place in a clear plastic bag (wrap many batteries together).
Instruction_3: Take batteries to a City Drop-Off Depot or Community Environment Day. For HHW from 10-50 L/kg, you can request a free pickup online or by calling 311.

Instruction_1: If you find a dead animal, contact 311. If found dead on private property, the animal needs to be bagged and placed at the curb for special pickup.
Instruction_2: You can also make an appointment to bring dead animals to a Toronto Animal Shelter for disposal.
Instruction_3: If the dead animal is under a deck or porch, please call a private company for animal removal.

Instruction_3: If the dead animal is under a deck or porch, please call a private company for animal removal.

Instruction_1: Do not touch the dead animal with your bare hands.
Instruction_2: Wear gloves or use a plastic bag to pick it up and put inside two plastic bags (double bag). Then tie the bags closed and place in the garbage.
Instruction_3: If you find the dead squirrel on City property (e.g. road, sidewalk, park) please contact 311 or double bag it and place it in the garbage.
